questions.text: A 46-year-old man who was found dead in his home was taken for a postmortem examination. It revealed clogging of the respiratory tract by semi-digested food particles consisting of rice and vegetable matter. This would fall under which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario is suggestive of aspiration of food particles, known as choking. It is a type of mechanical asphyxia, Suffocation.

Mechanical asphyxia can be classified depending on the respiratory block:

  1. Compression/constriction of the neck→ Hanging, strangulation (Option C), throttling
  2. Blocking external orificesof respiration, i.e., mouth and/or nostrils → Smothering (Option A), overlying, suffocation, gagging
  3. Impaction of foreign bodiesin the respiratory tract → Choking
  4. Compression and mechanical fixation of the chest and abdomen, preventing the respiratory movements → Traumatic asphyxia/crush asphyxia (Option B)
  5. Inhalation of fluidinto the respiratory tract → Drowning

Another classification is:

  1. Hanging → Complete hanging, Incomplete/partial hanging, Typical hanging, and Atypical hanging
  2. Strangulation→ Ligature strangulation, Manual strangulation/Throttling, Palmar strangulation, Mugging, Bansdola, and Garroting
  3. Suffocation:Smothering, Gagging, Choking, Traumatic asphyxia, Positional asphyxia, Burking, Overlaying/overlying, and Environmental suffocation
  4. Drowning→ Wet drowning (Classical/Typical/Primary drowning), Submersion of an unconscious person, Dry drowning, Immersion syndrome, and Secondary drowning (post-immersion syndrome)

choices.text: If larger than 2mm, it is known as ecchymosis
These spots are a reliable indicator of asphyxial death
Usually seen below the level of constriction

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding this postmortem finding on lungs in death due to asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Petechial haemorrhages (Tardieu spots). If larger than 2mm, it is known as ecchymosis.

Petechial Haemorrhages:

  • Usually round, dark, well-defined, and about the size of a pinhead, but may occasionally be larger.
  • Vary in size from 0.1 mm to about 2 mm.
  • If larger than 2mm, it is known as ecchymosis.
  • Due to the rupture of venules (Option A)
  • Tardieu spots are petechiae lying in the visceral pleura
  • Generally found in those parts where capillaries are least supported, e.g., Face, conjunctivae, epiglottis, heart and lung surfaces, brain, meninges and thymus
  • Usually seen above the level of constriction(e.g., strangulation) or compression (e.g., traumatic asphyxia) (Option D)
  • Not a definite sign of asphyxia (Option C)
  • May be found in other forms of death also, such as Acute haemorrhage, Scurvy, Purpura, Haemophilia, Coronary thrombosis, Electric shock, Poisoning etc., but distribution is mainly general

questions.text: In which of the following types of asphyxia can one see the most marked congestion and cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most marked congestion and cyanosis are seen in a case of traumatic asphyxia

Traumatic Asphyxia (Crush Asphyxia):

  • A form of asphyxia in which air entry into the lungs is inhibited by mechanical fixation of the chest → preventing respiratory movements.
  • Causes:
    • Earthquake
    • Building collapse
    • Stampede
    • Falling from a vehicle onto the chest in an RTA
    • Falling of luggage over the chest in Railway accidents, etc.
  • Mechanism:
    • Compression of the chest → Displacement of blood from the superior vena cava and subclavian veins into the smaller veins and capillaries of the head and neck → Rupture of their walls due to increased pressure → Deep cyanosis with multiple petechial haemorrhages
    • These signs are non-specific. But in traumatic asphyxia, there is a marked demonstration of congestion and cyanosis.
  • Post-mortem appearances:
    • Three cardinal external signs are:
      1. Multiple Petechial haemorrhages
      2. Cyanosis
      3. Clear-cut line of demarcation

Traumatic asphyxia

Explanation of other options:

Postural asphyxia (Option A): Results from body positioning that impairs ventilation; may show some cyanosis but not the marked facial congestion of crush asphyxia.

Smothering (Option C): External airway occlusion causes hypoxia without massive venous backflow; cyanosis is present but less pronounced.

Ligature strangulation (Option D): Neck compression impedes venous and arterial flow, producing facial congestion and petechiae, but without the dramatic cyanosis pattern seen in thoracic crush injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is best described by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts smothering.

  • Smothering is a form of asphyxia, caused by mechanical occlusion of external air passages, i.e., nose and mouth, by hand/s, cloth, pillow, plastic bag or any other material.
  • Bruises or abrasions on the cheeks, around the mouth, lips or lesions within the lips or mouth are the features of smothering.
  • Mechanical asphyxia can be classified depending on the respiratory block:
    1. Compression/constriction of the neck: Hanging, strangulation, throttling
    2. Blocking external orifices of respiration, i.e., mouth and/or nostrils - Smothering, overlying, suffocation, gagging
    3. Impaction of foreign bodies in the respiratory tract - Choking
    4. Compression and mechanical fixation of the chest and abdomen, preventing respiratory movements - Traumatic asphyxia/crush asphyxia
    5. Inhalation of fluid into the respiratory tract - Drowning

Explanation of other options:

Burking (Option A): It is a form of asphyxia, caused by the combination of Smothering and Traumatic asphyxia

Throttling (Option C) or Manual strangulation: It is a form of strangulation in which the neck is constricted by using hand/hands

Choking (Option D): It is a form of asphyxia, caused by occlusion of the internal air passage, usually by a solid object, but maybe by blood

choices.text: Congestion of the face indicates asphyxial death
Pressure marks on the face indicate smothering
Abrasion around the mouth indicates smothering

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding smothering?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abrasions around the mouth, cheeks, lips or lesions within the lips may reliably indicate smothering.

In homicidal smothering:

  • Abrasions and bruises around the nose and mouth (May not be seen if soft material is used)
  • Abrasions, bruises or small lacerations over the inner aspect of the lips and in the frenulum (Due to the pressure of the teeth)
  • Bruising of gums and tears in the soft tissue
  • A slight amount of froth in the air passages
  • Signs of struggle may be present
  • Other signs of asphyxia, such as cyanosis, congestion and petechial haemorrhages (But these are not specific to death due to smothering).

Non-specific signs in deaths due to asphyxia:

  • Petechial haemorrhages in the face, eyebrows, eyelids, forehead, ears, conjunctiva, and sclera - When they occur in the visceral pleura, they are called Tardieu's spots
  • Emphysematous, congested lungs with serosanguinous fluid exudates in alveoli
  • Cyanosis or dark-colored blood due to the accumulation of CO,
  • Congestion of the larynx with slight oozing

Explanation of other options:

Congestion of the face (Option A) and Intrathoracic petechiae (Option B) are nonspecific to smothering.

Pressure marks on the face (Option C) can rarely be distinguished from post-mortem postural changes, where circumoral and circumnasal pallor is caused merely by passive pressure of the dependent head after death, preventing the gravitational hypostasis from entering these areas.

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Burking is a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

  • Burking is a method of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
  • Historical context: Between 1827 and 1828 in Edinburgh, William Burke and William Hare lured victims to Hare's lodging house, gave them alcohol, then Burke would kneel on the victim's chest and cover their nose and mouth while Hare secured the legs. They sold the bodies to Dr. Robert Knox, murdering at least 16 people before detection.
  • Forensic hallmarks: Marked facial cyanosis, perioral abrasions from hand pressure, anterior chest petechiae, and absence of classic ligature or neck injuries distinguish burking from pure smothering or strangulation.

Explanation of other options:

Garroting (Option B): It is a form of strangulation, in which the victim is strangled from behind without warning, usually by a ligature

Throttling (Option C) or Manual strangulation: It is a form of strangulation in which the neck is constricted by using a hand/hands.

Bansdola (Option D): It is a form of strangulation in which the neck is constricted by bamboo/sticks/rods.

choices.text: Autopsy shows food lodged in the larynx only
Death is due to respiratory arrest
Death is often due to parasympathetic overactivity

questions.text: A 56-year-old man collapsed suddenly during dinner with his friends. They brought him to the ER, but he was already dead. On asking further history, they revealed that they were drinking before having food. There were no signs of asphyxia, but on autopsy, a bolus of food lodged in the larynx was found. Which of the following statements about this syndrome is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario is most likely suggestive of cafe coronary syndrome. Death in cafe coronary syndrome occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity. It is sudden and unexpected and happens rapidly.

Cafe Coronary Syndrome:

  • The victim may be observed slumping over the dining table or collapsing suddenly while walking across the room after having meals, with no signs of respiratory distressor any of the 'classic signs of asphyxia'.
  • The original series of deaths involved well-nourished businessmen dying suddenly and unexpectedly in restaurants and cafes, while sitting or shortly after sitting in their chairs, as if they had died of a heart attack. Hence, the name 'cafe coronary'. (Option A ruled out)
  • However, an autopsy usually reveals a bolus of food in the pharynx or larynx. (Option B ruled out)
  • Many cases have been reported where the victim was merely seen dead while sitting or just after sitting in a chair, the mode of death probably being cardiac arrest (Option C ruled out) due to overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system through the stimulation of branches of vagus nerve supplying the laryngeal and/or pharyngeal mucosa.
  • A fairly high level of alcohol has been found in most cases of cafe coronary deaths.
  • The suppression of the gag reflex due to alcohol or drugs makes the individual susceptible to this calamity.
  • Senile persons in retirement homes and mentally retarded children in institutions are also vulnerable.

choices.text: A pale face with no petechiae
Bleeding from the nose and mouth
Dribbling of saliva from the mouth
Absence of fracture of thyroid cartilage

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady was found dead with a ligature mark around her neck. Which among the following findings indicates death due to ligature strangulation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bleeding from the nose, mouth, and ears is commonly associated with death due to ligature strangulation.

choices.text: The most common fracture in manual strangulation is that of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage
Damage to the larynx is more severe in ligature strangulation
The greater horns of the hyoid are displaced medially in the case of manual strangulation
Lack of bleeding indicates postmortem fractures

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding laryngeal fractures in cases of manual and ligature strangulation is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Damage to the laryngeal structures is more in manual strangulation than in ligature strangulation.

  • During manual strangulation, the larynx may become damaged in various ways. The pressure is mainly bilateral, so that the sides of the larynx are squeezed. Particularly vulnerable structures are the four 'cornuae' or horns (greater cornuae of hyoid bone and superior horns of thyroid cartilage). (Option A)
  • The lateral pressure of the fingers can displace any of the four horns inwards, either by direct pressure or by pressure on the thyrohyoid membrane, which then drags the horns medially. (Option C)
  • There will be a haemorrhage at the fracture site that will make the lesion obvious (No haemorrhage in postmortem fracture) (Option D)
  • The cricoid and the main ala of the thyroid cartilage may be cracked.
  • Damage to the laryngeal cartilage is much less common in ligature strangulation than in manual strangulation.

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a metal collar around the neck and tightened by a lever from behind, known as the Spanish windlass technique, which is a type of garroting.

  • Garroting: It is a form of strangulation, in which the victim is strangled from behind without warning, usually by a ligature

Spanish Windlass Technique:

  • It was a method of judicial execution in Spain & Turkey
  • A metal collar around the neck was tightened by a lever from behind
  • It's a method of garroting (Although not as per definition)

Explanation of other options:

Burking (Option A): It is a form of asphyxia, caused by the combination of Smothering and Traumatic asphyxia

Lynching (Option C): A group of people acting together, overpower an individual, and hang him from a tree, or electric post or any other similar object by using a rope

Bansdola (Option D): It is a form of strangulation in which the neck is constricted by bamboo/sticks/rods

questions.text: Anteroposterior compression fracture of the hyoid bone is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anteroposterior compression fracture of the hyoid bone is seen in cases of death by hanging.

  • In case of hanging, the hyoid bone gets compressed between the ligature anteriorly and the cervical spine posteriorly, which leads to anteroposterior compression fracture and the fractured ends are displaced outwards (Abduction fracture).

Explanation of other options:

Burking (Option A) combines smothering and chest compression; hyoid fractures are rare due to a lack of ligature constriction.

Throttling (Option C) (manual strangulation): The pressure from the finger pulps and the fingertips on the hyoid bone compresses the greater Cornuae inwards, gets fractured, and the fractured ends are displaced inwards (Inward compression fracture or adduction fracture)

Smothering (Option D): External airway occlusion without neck constriction; the hyoid bone is not fractured.

questions.text: A person was brought dead, and an autopsy was performed to find the cause of death. The following findings were noted on examination. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given autopsy image shows multiple small bruises over the front of the neck, which are suggestive of death due to throttling.

Throttling (Manual strangulation):

  • Marks of bruising and ecchymosis are usually found on the front or sides of the neck, mainly over and above the larynx.
  • Six-penny bruises are multiple, small bruises caused by fingertips & finger pulps.
  • Other findings in throttling:
    • Ecchymosis in the subcutaneous tissues of the neck
    • Extensive bruising in the neck muscles
    • Intimal tear in the carotid artery in 10 -15% of cases
    • Hyoid bone fracture in 30-50% of cases (The fractured ends are directed inwards)
    • Fracture of the superior horn of thyroid cartilage (Common)
    • Cricoid cartilage may show a fracture
    • Mucosal haemorrhages in the interior of the larynx immediately below the vocal cords
    • Other signs such as a congested and cyanosed face with multiple petechial haemorrhages, prominent eyes with congested conjunctivae and subconjunctival haemorrhages, bleeding in the nose and ears, etc.

Explanation of other options:

Ligature strangulation (Option B): Ligature mark present; nail marks may also be seen.

Hanging (Option C): Typically shows a ligature mark, often oblique and above the thyroid cartilage.

Mugging (Option D): Neck compressed between the elbow or the knee; may show signs of asphyxia but no external bruises on the neck as compression is via soft tissues.

questions.text: Police were investigating a serial killer who hanged his victims upside down, which eventually led to their deaths. What is the most likely cause of death in these victims?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an inverted crucifixion, death occurs due to postural asphyxia.

Postural/Positional Asphyxia:

  • It is a form of asphyxia, caused by the exclusion of air from the lungs due to the abnormal position of the body.
  • In the case of inverted crucifixion, asphyxia occurs as a result of the impedance of inspiration by the weight of the abdominal viscera upon the diaphragm.

Explanation of other options:

Traumatic Asphyxia (Option B) is a form of asphyxia, in which air entry into the lungs is inhibited by mechanical fixation of the chest → preventing respiratory movements

Suffocation (Option A) is a type of asphyxia caused by either due to lack of oxygen in the environment (Environmental suffocation) or mechanical obstruction to the air passage by means other than constriction of the neck and drowning.

Mechanical asphyxia (Option D): Asphyxia by mechanical/physical forces.

questions.text: Jackknife position causes death due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Jack-knife position may cause death, usually by positional asphyxia and occasionally by traumatic asphyxia.

  • Jack-knife position is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest, causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.
  • Persons who have been trapped upside down or even only in a 'jack-knife' position, with the upper half of their body bent acutely downwards from the waist, may have such impairment of their respiratory movements that they become hypoxic and suffer marked disturbance of their circulatory system, especially the venous return to the heart.
  • Occasionally, traumatic asphyxia results from indirect compression, when the body is subjected to force in such a manner that his thighs and knees are driven against his chest, the so-called "jack-knife" position.

Explanation of other options:

Wedging (Option A) is impaction between objects; not characteristic of jack-knife positioning.

questions.text: What is this type of strangulation known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The type of strangulation shown in the given image is mugging.

Mugging:

  • The term strictly means throttling by pressure from an arm held around the throat.
  • The attack is usually made from behind, the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow.
  • Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx (Air choke or Bar arm control) or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm (Blood choke or Carotid sleeper hold).
  • Mugging is typically a quick, surprise manoeuvre during an assault or robbery, distinct from premeditated ligature or manual strangulation.

Explanation of other options:

Garroting (Option A): It is a form of strangulation in which the victim is strangled from behind without warning, usually by a ligature.

Bansdola (Option B): It is a form of strangulation in which the neck is constricted by bamboo/Sticks/Rods.

Burking (Option D): It is a form of asphyxia, caused by the combination of Smothering and Traumatic asphyxia.

questions.text: The weight of the head, arms, and chest acts as a constricting force in which of the following types of hanging?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The weight of the head, arms, and chest acts as a constricting force in partial hanging.

Types of hanging:

  • Complete hanging (Option A) → The body is completely suspended. The weight of the entire body acts as a constricting force.
  • Partial hanging → The body is partially suspended. The weight of the head (5-6 kgs), arms, and chest acts as a constricting force.
  • Typical hanging (Option C): Ligature knot positioned at the occipital region (back of the neck).
  • Atypical hanging (Option D): Ligature knot placed anywhere other than the occiput (e.g., under the chin, on the side).

choices.text: Jugular vein + Carotid artery + Trachea + Vertebral artery

questions.text: 15 kg of tension in the ligature around the neck is enough to occlude which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

About 15 kg of tension in the ligature around the neck occludes the jugular vein, carotid artery and trachea.

Sequence of Collapse:

  • Initial venous congestion → cerebral ischemia → airway compromise → vertebral artery involvement at very high tension.

questions.text: A victim of a suicidal hanging is brought to you for examination. All the following lead to the death of this patient except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laryngeal spasm is not a cause of death in suicidal hanging.

Laryngeal spasm is a transient reflex closure of the vocal cords and does not, by itself, cause death in hanging; the lethal mechanisms are mechanical and vascular, not glottic reflex.

Causes of Death in Hanging:

  1. Asphyxia (Fatal hypoxia → when O2 Level falls < 20% of normal)
  2. Venous congestion
  3. Combined asphyxia & Venous congestion
  4. Cerebral ischemia
  5. Reflex vagal inhibition
  6. Fracture or dislocation of cervical vertebrae

Explanation of other options:

Ischemic neuronal death (Option A): Ligature constriction occludes the carotid arteries, leading to cerebral hypoxia and irreversible neuronal damage.

Disruption of the vertebral column (Option B): In high-drop or judicial hangings, cervical vertebral fractures or dislocations can sever the spinal cord, causing instant death.

Vagal inhibition (Option D): Pressure on the carotid sinus may trigger a vagal reflex, arresting the heart, often "vagal shutdown," contributing to rapid collapse.

choices.text: The mark completely encircles the neck
The gap in the hanging mark indicates the point of suspension
The hanging mark is situated above the thyroid cartilage
The mark dries to a parchment-like consistency postmortem

questions.text: The body of a person who committed suicide by hanging was brought to your casualty. Which of the following is an unlikely finding to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hanging marks rarely completely encircle the neck unless a slipknot was used.

Hanging mark has the following features:

  • The point of suspension is indicated by a gap in the skin mark. This gap is usually seen on one or the other side of the neck or at the centre of the back of the neck. Much less often, it is under the chin. (Option B)
  • It is situated higher above the thyroid cartilage (In ≈ 80% of cases)(Option C). Being directly under the chin anteriorly, passing round beneath the jawbones and rising at the sides or back of the neck to the usual gap under the knot.
  • The mark may be abraded, brown, and dried to a parchment-like consistency after death. (Option D)
  • Narrow red zone either above or below (or both sides) of the ligature mark - Due to displacement of blood laterally from under the zone of maximum pressure.

choices.text: Ligature mark above the thyroid cartilage

questions.text: Which of the following findings will not be seen in suicidal hanging?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tears of the vertebral artery are not seen in cases of typical suicidal hanging. They require exceptionally high compressive forces or extreme cervical injury (e.g., judicial drop hangings)

Autopsy Findings in Hanging:

  • Postmortem lividity: Most marked on the skin of the dependent arms and legs. Glove & stocking pattern of postmortem lividity seen in vertically suspended bodies. (Option B)
  • Face: Usually pale and placid (due to complete constriction of vasculature). But in some cases where the constriction of the vessels is not complete, the face may be livid and swollen with profuse petechiae in the head and neck.
  • Eyeballs: May appear prominent due to congestion
  • Tongue: Turgid due to congestion, may protrude due to pressure at its base by the ligature and the exposed part may become dark brown or even black as a result of drying.
  • Dribbling of saliva: Seen in some cases. If seen, found dribbling from the corner of the mouth opposite to the side of the knot. It is due to the stimulation of the pterygopalatine ganglion/salivary glands. It is a definite sign of antemortem hanging.
  • 'La Facies Sympathique': It results from uneven ligature pressure crushing one cervical sympathetic trunk, causing ptosis on that side, while the opposite eye stays wide open with a dilated pupil.
  • Ligature mark:Usually Oblique. In roughly 80% of cases, above the level of thyroid cartilage, in 15% of cases over the thyroid cartilage and in 5% below the level of thyroid cartilage. (Option D)
  • Amussat's sign: Transverse tear of the intima of the carotid artery with extravasation of blood within the wall. (Option C)
  • Laryngeal fractures: The Superior horns of the thyroid cartilage may be fractured from pressure on the thyrohyoid ligament. The hyoid bone is fractured in 15-20% of cases.
  • Simon's Haemorrhages/Simon's sign:Seen beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament of intervertebral discs in lower thoracic & lumbar vertebrae. It is due to the overstretching of the spine because of the free suspension of the body (e.g., hanging).

choices.text: Between the chin and the ear

questions.text: A serial murderer has been sentenced to death by hanging. Where will the knot for the ligature be placed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The knot in a case of judicial hanging is placed below the ear in India.

  • A legal death sentence is carried out by hanging the criminal.
  • The face of the person is covered with a dark mask, and he is made to stand on a platform above trapdoors.
  • A rope to allow a drop of five to seven metres according to the weight, build and age of the person, is looped around the neck, with the knot under the angle of the jaw.
  • This placement maximises rotational force on the neck during the drop, promoting rapid dislocation of the upper cervical vertebrae and swift death.
  • Knot placement influences the vector of force: mastoid placement produces a lateral snap ("hangman's fracture") at C2.
  • Although placing the knot beneath the chin (Option B), i.e., the submental position is said to be a more effective way (slipping is a disadvantage), a knot at the left angle of the jaw (below the ear) is the most widely practised method of judicial hanging in India.
  • Between chin and ear (Option A) positions the knot too far forward, providing an insufficient lever arm to generate the rapid neck extension required for a clean cervical fracture.
  • High knot positions, like at the occiput (Option C), risk decapitation or inconsistent injuries.

questions.text: The autopsy findings of a person who died due to hanging showed the presence of haemorrhages in the intervertebral disc of the lumbar spine. What are these called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Simon's haemorrhages are streaky, linear bleeds beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament over the intervertebral discs, most commonly in the lower thoracic and lumbar spine.
  • They result from overextension and stretching of the vertebral column during free suspension (as in hanging), causing small-capillary rupture beneath the ligament.
  • Although classic for hanging, similar haemorrhages may appear in other scenarios of spinal overextension (e.g., falls, vehicular trauma) and even as postmortem artefacts in decomposed bodies.

questions.text: Seminal stains found around the legs of the victim are an absolute indicator of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The finding of the emission of semen at autopsy is a non-specific finding and does not indicate sexual activity or any particular mode of death.
  • The mere emission of semen found at autopsy does not confirm sexual activity in itself, as post-mortem discharge of semen from the meatus is common in any type of death, not only in asphyxia. (Option B ruled out)
  • Rigour in the dartos muscle causes compression of the testis & epididymis. Meanwhile, there will be contraction of the seminal vesicle & prostate, which leads to postmortem extrusion of semen. Most common in suspended bodies (e.g., Hanging)

Autoerotic Asphyxia:

  • Partial asphyxia caused by pressure on carotid vessels, or partial obstruction of air passages (by hanging, smothering, etc.), causes cerebral disturbances and may lead to hallucinations of an erotic nature in some men.
  • The degree of asphyxia produced by mechanical means is controlled, but in some cases, death occurs accidentally.
  • These cases are associated with some form of abnormal sexual behaviour usually, masochism and transvestism.
  • The presence of seminal stains alone is insufficient to diagnose this. Confirmation requires corroborative paraphernalia and contextual clues. (Option A ruled out)
  • Semen on the body does not prove recent intercourse nor link the death to a sexual assault or homicide. Forensic conclusions require injury patterns, DNA, and scene indicators. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Haemorrhage on the posterior surface of the oesophagus
Haemorrhage on the anterior longitudinal ligament
Pale areas in the oesophageal mucosa causing banding
Haemorrhage over the front of the larynx

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not considered a spurious lesion in the neck during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bleeding over the front and sides of the larynx is usually genuine and not a spurious lesion.

The following are the spurious haemorrhages:

  1. Prinsloo and Gordon artefact:
    • Apparent "bruising" of the neck musculature does not always indicate compression of or trauma to the neck.
    • Substantial haemorrhage may be seen over the posterior surface of the oesophagus (Option A) & anterior longitudinal ligament (Option B) of the cervical spine.
    • This can be prevented by bloodless dissection of the neck.
  2. 'Banding' of the oesophagus:
    • These bands are pale areas in the mucosa caused by post-mortem hypostasis being prevented from settling by the external pressure of adjacent anatomical structures, including parts of the larynx, trachea and aortic arch. (Option C)

questions.text: Bansdola is a form of strangulation by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bansdola:

  • It is a form of strangulation in which the neck is constricted by bamboo/sticks/rods
  • Usually, two bamboos or wooden poles or sticks or rods are used
  • One end of these sticks or bamboos is tied together by a rope
  • The other ends are brought forcefully together so as to squeeze or compress the neck in between two sticks to cause death
  • When a foot or knee is placed across the front of the throat and pressed while the victim is lying on the ground, the same condition will follow.
  • If a stick or foot is used, a bruise is seen in the centre, across the trachea, corresponding to the width of the object used.

Explanation of other options:

Ligature (Option A) strangulation uses cords or ropes encircling the neck.

Hands (Option B): Manual strangulation applies fingertip or palm pressure directly to neck structures.

Bend of elbow (Option D): Characteristic of mugging or armbar holds, not bansdola.

questions.text: Ligature mark is horizontal in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ligature mark is usually horizontal in strangulation.

Ligature Mark:

  • Caused as a result of the pressure of the ligature over the skin.
  • It is a Pressure abrasion.
  • It is a well-defined groove or furrow, which is slightly depressed and of the same width as that of the ligature material.
  • Groove may be narrow at parts due to the folding of the ligature.
  • Ligature mark in strangulation:Usually situated at the level of the thyroid cartilage or below. Usually situated transversely (Rarely oblique) & completely encircles the neck

Ligature mark in hanging (Option A): Usually Oblique. In ≈ 80% of cases, it is situated above the level of thyroid cartilage, in ≈ 15% of cases over the thyroid cartilage and ≈ 5% of cases below the level of thyroid cartilage

questions.text: Hangman's fracture is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hangman's fracture consists of a fracture of the pedicles of the axis, resulting in anterior dislocation (spondylolisthesis) of C2 on C3 with or without odontoid process fracture. This injury is typically met in judicial hangings and vehicular accidents in which the neck is forcibly hyperextended and rotated.
  • Hangman's fracture is common in cases where the knot in judicial hanging is in the submental position.
  • In the typical subaural position, the typical hangman's fracture is rare.

Explanation of other options:

Fracture of odontoid process (Option B): Involves the dens; known as a Type II odontoid fracture, not a Hangman's fracture.

Fracture of transverse process (Option C): Rare and unrelated to the pedicle injuries defining Hangman's.

Dislocation of C5 (Option D): A lower cervical injury; not characteristic of axis pedicle fractures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old fisherman was brought dead. His autopsy findings revealed emphysema aquosum. What is the most probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Emphysema aquosum is seen in cases of wet drowning.

Lung's findings in the case of wet drowning:

  • The lungs are voluminous, may completely cover the pericardial sac, and bulge out of the chest when the sternum is removed. This is known as ballooning and is due to the presence of fluid and air in the bronchi.
  • The lungs are overdistended, and the alveolar walls are torn.
  • The oedema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death, holding the lungs in the inspiratory position.
  • In addition, there is often an element of over-distension caused by the valvular action of bronchial obstruction. This produces an impression of ribs (grooves) on the lateral surface of the lungs, which is an important sign of drowning.
  • On a section, an oedematous condition due to the presence of watery, frothy, sometimes blood-stained fluid is seen.
  • Drowning fluid penetrates alveolar walls to enter the tissues and the blood vessels.
  • This has been described as emphysema aquosum.

Definite signs of antemortem drowning:

  1. Cadaveric Spasm with weeds/grass in the hand
  2. Emphysema aquosum
  3. A copious amount of white, fine, leathery froth (D/t Emphysema Acquosum)
  4. Paltauf's haemorrhages
  5. Diatoms (The medico-legal importance of diatoms is controversial. If the same species of diatoms present in the drowning media is present in bone marrow, and if the victim had not drunk the same water before submersion is the most important internal sign of antemortem drowning.)

Near Drowning = The victim survives the drowning episode

Reference: https://www.healthline.com/health/near-drowning

choices.text: Can be either homicidal or suicidal

questions.text: On examining a case of wet drowning, you observe weights that are attached to the body to keep it underwater. What does this suggest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Attachment of weights to the body to keep it underwater is consistent with both homicidal and suicidal drowning.

Suicidal drowning (Option B): A determined suicidal person may attach weights to the body or tie their limbs. It is common among women.

Homicidal drowning (Option A): The assailant may attach weight to his victim's body to keep it underwater to conceal the evidence. In addition, there may be signs of struggle on the body, or evidence of struggle at the banks of the river from where the body was recovered.

Weights on a drowned body indicate deliberate submersion but cannot distinguish suicide from homicide without supporting scene or autopsy evidence. Comprehensive evaluation includes shoreline investigation, defensive injuries, and toxicology.

Explanation of other options:

Accidental drowning (Option D) is the most common form of drowning. It is seen among fishermen, bathers, dock workers, the intoxicated, and epileptics. Homicidal drowning is the least common.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man drowns while on an arctic cruise by accidentally falling overboard with a horizontal entry into the sea. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death for this individual?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of immersion syndrome/ hydrocution/ submersion inhibition. Death results from cardiac arrest due to vasovagal inhibition followed by cardiac arrest.

Immersion Syndrome (Hydrocution, submersion inhibition):

  • Death resulting from cardiac arrest due to vagal inhibition, after immersion in liquid.
  • Incidence: 1-2% cases of drowning
  • Causes:
    • Icy cold water stimulates the nerve endings at the surface of the body
    • Cold water entering the eardrums, nasal passages, pharynx and larynx stimulates nerve endings at the mucosal surfaces
    • Water striking the epigastrium
  • Circumstances:
    • Diving into the water feet first
    • Diving with horizontal entry in water (with consequent blow on the Abdomen)
    • "Duck diving" by the inexperienced ("Duck diving" is a surfing term in which the surfer pushes the surfboard underwater).
  • Aggravating factors:Alcohol and emotional tension (As in cases of suicide)

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral oedema (Option A) is seen in cases of Secondary drowning (Post-immersion syndrome).

Pulmonary oedema (Option B) is the cause of death in typical drowning/primary drowning due to inhalation of water into the lungs.

Laryngeal spasm (Option D) is the cause of death in dry drowning.

Reference: https://www.healthline.com/health/near-drowning

questions.text: The dead body of a man was retrieved from a lake. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities would you expect to find in him?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Freshwater drowning (drowning in a lake) is associated with both hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

  • When freshwater (hypotonic to plasma) enters the alveolar spaces, it is rapidly absorbed into the pulmonary circulation, resulting in gross hemodilution.
    • This massive increase in blood volume leads to hemolysis with the liberation of potassium.
    • This causes hyperkalemia with corresponding dilutional hyponatremia.
    • Hyperkalemia leads to ventricular fibrillation.
  • When seawater enters, due to high saline content, reverse osmosis flow occurs.
    • The fluid leaves the circulation and enters the alveolar spaces.
    • This causes hemoconcentration, hypernatremia and pulmonary oedema.
    • Hypernatremia leads to bradycardia and cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolytes is measured in Gettler's test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gettler's test measures the chloride content of the left and right sides of the heart.

Gettler's Test:

  • Normally, the chloride content of the left and right sides of the heart is almost the same (about 600 mg per 100 ml).
  • The difference between the two chambers may not be more than 5 mg/100 ml
  • According to Gettler, a difference of 25 mg% between the chloride.
  • Concentrations of the two sides of the heart were an indication of death due to drowning.
  • Freshwater drowning - chloride content of the left heart is lower than that of the right heart
  • Saltwater drowning - chloride content of the right heart is lower than that of the left heart.

Procedure:

  • Dry the surface of the heart.
  • Punctured with a knife.
  • Withdraw 20 ml of blood from each ventricle of the heart, using separate dry pipettes.
  • Analyze.

Limitations of Gettler's test:

  • There is a progressive loss of chloride from the blood after death.
  • In atypical drowning, the test is of no value, as water doesn't enter the respiratory passages.
  • In congenital cardiac defects, such as a septal defect, foramen ovale, etc., the test has no value.
  • If the drowning medium and blood contain the same amount of chlorides, the test will have no value.

questions.text: Identify the following finding in a victim of drowning:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image given shows the washerwoman's foot (Skin maceration). It occurs faster in warm water than in cold water.

Washer woman's hands and feet:

  • Due to the absorption of water into the outer layers of skin
  • Starts at fingertips
  • Occurs early in warm water
  • Seen in about 24 hours
  • It's only a sign of immersion
    • 2-4 hours: Wrinkling & soddening of fingertips
    • 4-8 Hours: Bleaching of epidermis
    • 24 hours: The Entire hand shows a bleached, wrinkled and soddened appearance (Washer woman's Hands/Feet)
    • 48 hours: Peeling of cuticle from palm and sole
    • 3-4 days: Skin can be peeled off like a glove

Cutis anserina (Goose skin/flesh/bump)

  • Granular & puckered appearance of skin
  • Due to the spasm of the arrector pili muscle due to cold
  • Especially seen over the thighs
  • Also seen in the case of rigour mortis of the arrector pili muscles

Postmortem lividity:

  • In running water (river), → will be absent
  • In stagnant water, the body usually floats face down, buttocks up, with limbs hanging down. So, seen in Face, the upper part of the chest, hands & forearms and feet & legs

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman's body was retrieved from a manhole. You are suspecting antemortem drowning. Which of the following signs will most likely support your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cadaveric spasm (also known as instantaneous rigour or cataleptic rigidity, or instantaneous rigidity) is an important sign of antemortem drowning.

  • It manifests as closed hands with firmly grasped weeds, grass, sticks, etc., floating in the water. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.
  • Cadaveric spasm is a rare form of muscular stiffening that occurs at the moment of death and persists into the period of rigour mortis.
  • The image given below shows a cadaveric spasm of a hand holding grass, as seen in antemortem drowning.

Explanation of other options:

Petechial haemorrhages (Option A) in the eyes are one of the non-specific signs of death due to asphyxia, but are not seen in the case of drowning.

Cutis anserina (Option B) (Goose skin/flesh/bump): Granular & puckered appearance of skin due to the spasm of the arrector pili muscle due to cold. Especially seen over the thighs. Also seen in the case of rigour mortis of the arrector pili muscles.

Skin maceration (Option D): Also known as washerwoman's hands and feet. It is due to the absorption of water into the outer layers of the skin. It is a non-specific sign of immersion, occurring in both ante- and post-mortem submersion, and cannot by itself confirm antemortem drowning.

questions.text: Where are Paltauf's haemorrhages seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paltauf's haemorrhages are seen in the lungs as subpleural haemorrhages.

Paltauf's haemorrhages (Paltauf's spots):

  • Appearance→ Shining, pale pink or bluish red haemorrhages, immediately beneath the pleurae (Subpleural space).
  • Size → Minute or up to 3-5 cm in diameter
  • Incidence → 50%.
  • Location → Lower lobes of lungs (most common). It may also be on the interlobar surfaces or the anterior surfaces of the entire lungs.
  • Mechanism → Tearing (rupture) of the interalveolar partitions due to decreased pressure during forced expirations

questions.text: The outer covering of a diatom is made of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The outer covering of a diatom is made of silica.

Diatoms:

  • Microscopic, unicellular algae vary from one water medium to another
  • Varies in shape & size (2μ to 1 mm)
  • Maximum size that can enter into pulmonary circulation → 40μ.
  • They have a complex structure of their cell walls, which are usually strongly impregnated with silica
  • The outer siliceous (silica) coat is known as → Frustule
  • Frustule is resistant to heat, acid & putrefaction
  • Examined by the acid digestion technique
  • Best organ for diatom study → Femur
  • Most commonly used bone → Sternum
  • Most preferred soft organ → Kidney
